title: How to prepare for the NEET from the very beginning without coaching - Quora

response.answer_text: Thanks for A2A. Now before writing this answer I’d specify that I had a few friends during my preparation time who relied on self study for NEET. I’ll be enumerating what all I had observed from their methods of studying. It’s possible to get a good score in NEET UG without joining a coaching institute but there are a few things which are an absolute prerequisite for preparation and which you mustn’t bypass. You’ve got to join a test series. A single institute’s would do. Why is it necessary? Because of obvious reasons, besides giving you some handful of quality questions, it will tell you where you stand among the swarm of people preparing for the same competition.Get at least a teacher for doubt clearance. Tuition teacher or some school teacher or anyone who could help solve your queries especially for physics and chemistry. Doubts are notorious, since they pile up easily and erode your concept understanding as well as confidence.After you’ve fulfilled these two obligations, you’re good to go even without joining an institute. How do I prepare from the very beginning? Make a daily and fortnightly schedule. You should plan the number of topics/sub topics you must complete daily. Also make a similar fortnightly schedule. Take help from the syllabus of the mock tests you’re enrolled to, to plan the number of topics you should complete every 14 days.Try getting the materials of premiere coaching institutes. It’s easy. Editions which are 1/2 years old are easily available second hand in many markets these days. You can also ask your seniors to provide such materials. If you don’t object digital resources, you can find a lot of materials on internet and telegram. Coaching modules aren’t necessary as such, but they can be used since they’re crafted by experienced teachers who know the level of NEET exam better than most of others.One of the drawback of self study is being unsure about the “amount” of materials/books one should have. Limit yourself to just sufficient books. If you’re using Allen/Aakash modules, then there is no use going for 3–4 more coaching institutes modules, it’s a waste of time. Don’t buy Resnick Halliday, J D Lee and other such books unnecessarily. Keep only 1/2 books for each subject other than coaching materials(optional too). Nothing more than that.NCERT for biology. It’s easily gonna fetch you minimum 330/360 if you’ve done a double digit smart read. Apart from this use only one extra book for MCQs solving. Fingertips/Disha/Most Wanted/Aim4Aiims anything would work.For Physics and chemistry too, choose one book which has good theory in it with lots of questions. H C Verma/S L Arora/D C Pandey/Errorless. Whatever you solve, solve it single-mindedly. Stop the habit of doubting the book you’re using. It’s the number and quality of questions you solve, which determines your performance in NEET and not the Author’s name whose book you’re referring to. However, if the book is abundant with errors and you find the level of questions in it below NEET level, don’t hesitate from changing it. Inorganic chemistry only requires NCERT. The more you go for deeper theory from other books, the more you forget what is within the syllabus.Don’t be totally cut off from others. Make one or two good friends with whom you could discuss anything synergistically. However, everyone’s a competitor these days, so it’s best to make your guardians your best friends. Keep yourself updated with all the latest developments regarding NEET dates/syllabus/pattern etc, since you aren’t a coaching student who can rely on the teachers for such information.Utilise YouTube for video lectures of tough and tricky topics. It’s a resource at your disposal, which should be hunted smartly. Follow good channels and learn the concepts which they disseminate to understand the topics better.Vibhas K. Gupta's answer to What is the best channel for preparation for the NEET and AIIMS on YouTube? (Read other answers to this question too)Revise what you’ve studied, on every weekend/every second weekend. When you keep on advancing and keep on forgetting older concepts, your efforts turn out to be a futile one. So it’s wise to take a break to revise what all you’ve learnt after a sufficient time gap.Staying at home makes you prone to distractions and demotivation. Sandeep Maheshwari Sir wouldn’t help in this case. Motivation comes from within and is not infused by external sources. When the reason of your efforts is strong(The Why?), you don’t need any other source of motivation.Lastly, don’t search for examples, rather set an example yourself. :)Good luck. Thanks for reading!✌️

This answer is subject to newer edits, which are given right at the end. It is possible to crack NEET exam just with self study. Tuitions provide good guidance and a regular rhythm to your studies, but you can get through without them as well. On one hand, if you aren’t interested in attending a tuition for NEET, I’d sincerely advise you to be regular with your school. You can probably study on your own, but you’ll need teachers to clarify your doubts, moreover, regularly attending your school will help you build rhythm in your study. Now with the study part: 1.Biology Make NCERT your core book….. Honestly, as simple and basic NCERT appears, it is that more important for NEET-UG.Since you aren’t up for coaching, you’ll need some sort of book to elaborate and build upon your concepts. I advise you to consult regarding this with your school biology teacher, because I don’t know of any book out there that will build up sufficiently needed concepts in biology, probably because it isn’t there.Trueman, DLP programmes and everything else contain way too much than what’s necessary for NEET, so don’t dive into them……..You’ll only waste your time. For practice, I advise you to refer MTG Biology Guide, previous year chapterwise questions. You can also purchase Balaji books for Botany and Zoology, since you aren’t obtaining practice material from any coaching.Do purchase NCERT Exemplar book. It is an indicative material of good questions that are based on the concepts that you can form from NCERT.2. Chemistry A. Inorganic Chemistry NCERT, that’s it! NCERT is the best thing you can study for Inorganic.In inorganic, there’s already a lot to cram, and using NCERT not only can you save yourself from wasting your mind and stressing over a lot of unnecessary material, but you can also save a lot of time!For reference, you can use GRB’s Inorganic chemistry.B. Physical Chemistry Physical Chemistry needs a lot of practice and conceptual understanding, and NCERT doesn’t suffice, but it doesn’t mean, that you should ignore it. It has to be covered.For building proper concepts, use GRB’s Physical Chemistry.But remember, you don’t need to browse through the entire book! You just need to study the topics mentioned in NCERT and syllabus of NEET.You can study the rest if you feel like to gain an additional edge. C. Organic Chemistry Organic chemistry is divided into 4 branches: IUPAC nomenclature, Isomerism, General Organic Chemistry-1 (GOC-1) and GOC-2.IUPAC nomenclature and Isomerism - You need to build crystal clear concepts to do well in both these topics. It is advisable to use a refresher, so that you’ll learn a wider variety of concepts that are necessary, and also will gain exposure to questions. Both these topics are relatively easy to understand and you can score well.General Organic Chemistry 1 - GOC-1 involves understanding basic molecular properties like nucleophilicity, electrophilicity, resonance,etc. which are necessary to predict products of a reaction. It is important that you build these concepts well, and again I recommend using a refresher for this purpose.General Organic Chemistry 2 - GOC-2 involves important organic chemical reactions that you have to learn. For this part of organic, I sincerely recommend sticking to all the reactions given in NCERT, both of class 11th and 12th. All that’s given in those NCERTs is enough for GOC-2 to crack NEET. When I gave NEET, I only failed 1 or 2 questions in organic, and I went in just by studying all organic reactions given in NCERT, 2–3 times.3. Physics Physics is the most crucial part of NEET, and is the ultimate rank deciding subject. Most students who give NEET, excel at biology and Chemistry, but falter at Physics.NCERT won’t suffice for physics. You’ll need to build strong concepts, because success in physics can’t be achieved with rote memorization. But it doesn’t mean you should ignore NCERT. You should ideally give it a glance but not make it your core.I advise you to attend physics classes at your school regularly or join an only-physics coaching, because in physics a teacher’s input is invaluable.In physics, you’ll need to make a refresher as your core book for understanding physics. You need to ask your teacher for advice regarding this, else, if you join a physics tuition, refer the study material that the tuition teacher provides and make it your basic conceptual material.BOOKS TO REFER GENERALa. MTG NEET Explorer b. Previous Year Chapterwise (to be dealt with as you cover chapters by yourself) BiologyCore concepts - NCERT Practice - MTG Biology Guide, Balaji books for Botany and zoology 2. Chemistry Core concepts- Inorganic - NCERTOrganic - NCERT and any other reliable, understandable sourcePhysical - NCERT for basics and GRb for advanced concepts and better understandingPractice: MTG Chemistry Guide MS Chauhan &/or GRB for organic GRB or other relevant material for inorganic (doesn’t need a lot of practice,just sufficient cramming capacity) GRB or other relevant material for physical 3. Physics Core concepts - Tuition notes, every material out there is exhaustive, so I sincerely advise you to join a physics tuition rather than try physics out yourself. Practice - Tuition practice questions, MTG Physics Guide, HC Verma (for higher level practice) QUICK TIPS IN CONCLUSION Since you want to embark on a NEET journey all by yourself, I advise you to join a national level test series like Allen or Aakash’s AIATS, to stay competitive and know your position nation wide.Note- You may score poorly in these tests, because some questions come way out of NCERTs, based on concepts given in NCERT but are way out of what is necessary for NEET. 2. Practice You can’t ace any subject without practicing sufficient questions. This is even more pronounced with regards to subjects like physics , physical and organic chemistry….. So do keep practicing questions regularly. 3. For later stages/ preparation finales - solve timed question papers on an OMR sheet, for learning better skills in time management, that you’ll need when you ultimately take up the exam. Also gaining more practice on the OMR will minimize your chances of wrongly filling answers in the examination. 4. Don’t study material that is unnecessary, that are way above what’s necessary for NEET, just because someone recommends it to you. 5. It is a common mistake among students to consider NCERT as a simple, basic book and disregard its importance for NEET, thinking that they should have way higher knowledge. Remember, you don’t need a PhD, all you need is sufficient knowledge to crack the exam. This exhaustive answer would have served its purpose, even if it can become a part of someone’s successful journey to cracking NEET. Best of luck! Yours sincerely, Prateek EDIT 1- USS is also a good book for practicing physics EDIT 2 - MTG’s NCERT at your fingertips can also be referred in all three subjects. Should be referred at least in biology and chemistry if possible. Also NCERT exemplar books are recommended for all subjects…

To prepare for NEET, you need proper guidance. If you are a brilliant student then I would suggest you take your preparation alone. NEET 2019 will be held on the 5th of May. Along with NEET examination, you also have to prepare for your board examination. You also have to manage your syllabus as well. NEET exam comprises both class 11 and 12 syllabi, whereas you have to study only class 12 for your board examination. Therefore, you have to focus on particular chapters strategically to score good marks in NEET. To take admissions in government medical colleges, you have to score above 550. For such a huge score, you should have clear ideas about concepts. The ways you can prepare yourself for the examination A proper study plan is required where you can easily get a clear idea about the important chaptersAs per requirement, the students can manage his time. During the time of class 12 examination, the students can focus mostly on those chapters of class 12. Due to this a proper revision can also be managedNCERT books are the best way to score good marks in the examination.Practice question papers from previous years. Regular mock tests can also help you in scoring good marks in the examinationFor board examination, you have to practice maths as well, whereas for NEET examination there are only 3 subjects. If you are passionate about MBBS then think how to score good marks in these subjects: Physics, Chemistry and BiologyThe most difficult subjects in NEET is considered to be Physics. So the students have to study all the three subjects regularly. Physics can be improved only by practising calculations. Chemistry and Biology are all about theories. Focus on basic areas where you can score good marks. Suppose you are good at Biology, try to answer as many questions as possible from the subject. Similarly, for Chemistry, there are problems coming out of the formula. You should attempt those questions. The students are scared of Physics due to its difficulty level. Make a proper study plan without which you cannot understand your preparatory stages. Go through the link Ananya Chaudhuri's answer to What should be the daily routine to crack the NEET 2019? Other Issues faced by the students Usually, the students are stressed out during this time due to study pressureA regular revision is hampered due to board exams, therefore, the students should make a routine for grasping the concepts clearlyThe students suffer from sleep deprivation due to the strenuous timetable of preparation, they have to focus on how to utilize minimalistic time for learning new thingsIt is better to spend hours to engage in extracurricular activities. In this way, the students can enjoy the study as wellNEET 2018 difficulty level is also analyzed below, go through the question matrix and you can understand how to plan your timetable Ananya Chaudhuri's answer to What is the difficulty level of Physics Chemistry and Biology in NEET?

Learning from my own experiences, I can say that self study is the crux of sailing u through in this examination. For me the 3D’s to crack any exam is: DesireDilligenceDedicationAlso, LUCK is invariably a crucial factor. No doubt, I have got much benefit from AAKASH teachers and their study materials in my drop year. But if i have to look back, I probably could have made it without coaching. As the syllabus for the boards and Entrance exam is almost similar (except the question pattern), it would be a wise decision to start preparing right from class 11. Go through the NCERT textbooks religiously and certain reference books to make your concepts clear. For Biology, NCERT is more than sufficient. But in case of Physics and Chemistry, reference books helps a lot to grasp the concepts easily and solving numericals. I used to follow SL ARORA for physics, and N. AVASTHI for physical chemistry, NCERT and MODERN ABC for organic chemistry. Devote equal time to all three subjects especially Biology as it will ensure your selection. Now dont run after the books with which u are not comfortable with. Stick to one particular book rather than buying several books (and then later ending up doing nothing) and study regularly. You may complete the entire book, but if u dont revise it’s of no use; there is no substitute for REVISION. Try to practice MCQs daily to make yourself acquainted with the paper pattern. Previous year papers prove to be a boon in this case. NCERT at your Fingertips is also a nice book to be followed both for NEET and boards. Make crisp notes which u can revise few weeks before exam, as it isnot possible to study the entire book under such a limited time. “Your own handwritten notes are your best companion for study” If u really want to crack NEET in ur very 1st attempt without any coaching, u have to study smartly and religiously. Coaching institutes just provides u a direction and it is you who makes it upto the final list. Have a little faith in yourself, and study according to your own plans. Remember, success isnot a destination, it’s a journey. It’s high time now that u realise your dreams and with ur efforts and hard work bring the best possible result. Chase your Dream!

Dear, First of all just forget about the fact that “WITHOUT COACHING YOU ARE NOT ABLE TO CRACK COMPETITIVE EXAMS”. The most important thing that you should have during this time period is “YOUR CONFIDENCE”. Look the syllabus of neet and of class 11-12 are completely same but where the difference lies, is the pattern. In neet there are 180 questions and you have to solve that within 3 hrs/180 minutes. So the most important factor is speed. If you are in cbse board, things will be a little bit easier for you because you will have to read the same NCERT book for both NEET and boards. For biology don't go for other side books(like Trueman) . Stick to the NCERT and notes which you are making during your preparation phase. And solve more and more questions. If you don't know the answer of a particular question, bookmark that question for revision. If you have any doubts regarding any topic ask your school - teachers or seniors or you can watch a video regarding that topic from YouTube or unacademy app(I'll prefer unacademy app because it helps me a lot during my preparation). From chemistry point of view, if you read only NCERT you can easily solve the questions of organic and inorganic part which covers approximately 22-25 questions in Neet. Make your own notes and stick to that as well as NCERT. Solve questions from a standard book like GRB PUBLICATIONS /MS CHAUHAN(for organic) and also try to solve previous question papers of JEE MAINS and NEET. For physics, to be very frank NCERT is not going to help you. In my preparation phase I used to keep that book in the store room. Try to make your concepts crystal clear wrt physics. If you are weak in physics then make a copy in which you write all the possible formulas of each and every chapters and go through that copy everyday. Solve a lot of numerical as well as practise the previous question papers of NEET AND JEE MAINS. if you have a particular problem regarding any question throw that in front of your teacher. Don't hesitate to ask because questions can be asked from that topic. So you have to make your concepts very clear. And lastly - practice a full neet based question paper once a week during your boards exam and after boards try to solve a full 720 marks question paper per day. Trust me it will help you to boost your marks a lot. Thanks for reading. Hope it's going to help you :)

This year paper was like walk in the park so there High chances that next year it's gonna be a bit harder and if you are 2022 aspirant you have enough time but it's better to play on safe, considering 2022 NEET cut off gonna be high again. Yes, you can do it by self studying only but if you are fresher you must take some guidance from those having experience. Recommend you to take YouTube help and if you have any friend who has appeared NEET. How will you prepare?  Focus more on Physics. Obviously here you don't require theoretical reading like Biology, so concentrate more on MCQs, solve at least 100 to 150 MCQs daily. Gradually increase the level (hope you have Idea about MCQ books) starting from your basic level to advanced. Don't forget to solve previous year questions.Biology: Read NCERT text book as many times as you can. Ready every single line every corner and all the diagram, tables and flow charts perfectly, because almost 80 to 85 questions are asked from NCERT itself. These 80 to 85 questions can make you score 320 to 340 marks if won't reduce your score in negative marking. Since 2 years all 90 Questions were asked from NCERT only → refer the above image. You can secure your negative marks if you have solved so many MCQs and previous year questions.Chemistry: Do focus more on organic chemistry because it's easy to understand but the questions are tricky. Again solving MCQs will help you to develop tricks to solve the reaction quickly. Inorganic chemistry is more scoring if concepts are very clear.Must solve MOCK PAPERS or TEST SERIES before 20 to 30 days before exam. Keep some 7 to 10 days to revise complete syllabus.If required any help feel free to direct contact on telegram channel “NEET queries” link in my profile Swapnil Dange Wish you the great success… Thank you so much!!

Thanks for requesting. Yes..madam..u can crack NEET easily through self study..I did.. And if I can u will definitely able to..so let's get started.. BIOLOGY: u have to read NCERT line by line . cover to cover..diagrams..labellings.. everything..Actually u have been told same thing again and again..Now be specified..why it is so? As I had witnessed NEET 2019..there is around 82–83 questions came directly from NCERT..And I who can't be considered even good in biology scored that well..And if u just finish NCERT alone then also u r confirmed to get 300+ at any cost..So,my advice is…..Read NCERT..solve NEET pyq(upto 2000)..solve AIIMS pyq(upto 2006)…NCERT at your fingertips..and read also Rahul chawla's handbook of biology..that's more than enough..CHEMISTRY: now for physical chemistry..focus more on sums as it comes often..1stly if u have any module..then read from them…And if u r like me(😁)..then read from NCERT with some online short videos from YouTube for doubts..now focus more on NEET 32 yrs pyq than Fingertips or any question bank..As I found the concepts are more or less same for many questions every yr..Now for INORGANIC,read NCERT textbooks..(now some tricks can be consulted from ATP in YouTube specially for chemical bonding..bond angle problems etc.)….read Intext questions (I found one in NEET from group chemistry)..again more focus on NEET pyq and AIIMS pyq..finally.. ORGANIC CHEMISTRY, my fav ….focus deeply on GOC , HYDROCARBON..It has to be understood well..read from modules or read NCERT and do consult YouTube videos..also read NCERT..(in 2017, hydrocarbon configuration based one question copied from NCERT lines)so bttr to read..For class 12,solely dependent NCERTs..name reactions mechanisms of important ones..solve a lot.. from NEET pyq,JEE MAIN pyq(upto 2003)..MS chauchan can be solved if u have more than enough time..otherwise not preffered by me..PHYSICS:solve a lot..get formula book of Ur own..study from NCERT or modules …thoroughly solve NEET pyq..they are going to save u when u r revising as well as if u r slight weak in it..solve AIIMS pyq also..note the mistakes..solve same concept sums..solve NEET guide more than enough if u solve that much also and revised with every concept..Now..have u mentioned I suggested NEET pyq..in every sub..u will understand why once u cracked it..As if NEET is a big exam blf me it has its weak points..it's own previous year papers..There rarely changing any pattern..And u have to identify just it..Harm the host with its own parasite.. Be ready..be focused..u will get Ur drm..if u have any problem..msg me in inbox..will try to solve it.. Hope it helps..!!

Just follow this as much as you can.. And you will be there :) - Read this overall guide for your preparation: The Complete NEET-AIIMS Guide: 1. Be sincere in your efforts (Half hearted efforts do not give fruitful results!) 2. Practice from limited and standard books like SL Arora HC VERMA, etc. Don’t go for too many books. Do limited books, and do it more number of times. Become perfect in them. The end objective is to gain confidence. If you are able to get good marks and have gained confidence… That’s it. You are there.. One should create a balance between doing and non-doing… One should not over-do anything! Over-doing brings dullness and self-doubt. 3. Get a good Guru, if you can find ! Guru is the person who knows what should be done and what should not be done. He/she is the best guide. 4.Focus more on previous year questions of NEET,AIIMS and other medical exams that were conducted earlier (statewise). Books to be used for theory and numerical: Chemistry: NCERT-most important. Other than that, for reference, use OP Tandon, MS Chouhan, Himanshu Pandey, Pradeeps, Morrison and Boyd, SN Sanyal etc. For Physical and Organic, you need to refer some books. In that too, NCERT will cover 80%+. Refer other books for that 20% left. Otherwise NCERT is brilliant for Chem. BIO: Start with NCERT, . Then go ahead with previous year questions. You can also refer to Trueman’s for that little extra thing. 70-80 % NCERT will do. For that 20-30% extra, you need to refer to books like Truemans. Physics: Start with SL Arora and HC Verma. Then go ahead with previous year Questions directly. Also you can skip doing some questions of HC Verma if NEET is your target as they are meant for Engineering only.. Practice from MTG Books(as they are best for Medical with best solutions and almost all the answers are correct): MTG NEET Champion, NCERT at your fingertips, NEET Guide, MTG AIIMS Assertion and Reasons, MTG NEET 31 Years, MTG AIIMS 25 Years for all three subjects ! And if time permits, practice IIT JEE Mains questions too from Arihant 40 years (because many times questions repeat in Medical from IIT JEE). No need to do any other book!! No modules etc needed after this. But as I said, you should feel confident after this. That should come from within. Till that comes, keep practicing questions. Practice previous year questions MANY TIMES. Become perfect in them. Solve other people’s doubts. That will help you score better :) (Whatever we give to the world comes back many times. Example: If you keep smiling, then people smile at you. That’s the law of nature. You give Soan Papdi in Diwali to people and Soan Papdi will only come back. World is nothing but a reflection of you. Whatever you start thinking, starts manifesting. So always be positive. Be Happy and Spread the knowledge and it will come back to you !) People run after so many modules and crap test series (which are many times intentionally made tough by coaching institutes just to show off and students lose confidence after that. Just know one thing in life: Most important rule: WHATEVER YOU DO, WHATEVER HAPPENS, NEVER LOSE YOUR CONFIDENCE. Even if you fall, stand up again. And only those people fail, who try!). Instead you should focus on limited material and do it more number of times!! Many questions ask only basic concepts but a good clarity in them. Self study is definitely most important. But one thing I would like to say, even diamonds need to be polished to shine. So coaching brings that effect. If you have potential, a good coach can help you perform on that potential. So find one good Guru for yourself if you can! Time Management: Never look at what the clock is ticking.. You should study in a target based manner. A good candidate should do atleast 120 questions per day (PCB Combined) (and whatever time it takes. If it takes 2 hours, well enough. Enjoy after that. But if it requires whole day, be ready to give it. After all, its about your dream and your whole life!) . And every week, one should revise all his/her self made notes. If that happens whole year, marks my words: Result is guaranteed.. J Also, don’t be so harsh on yourself. Life is a combination of being rigid and being flexible. You can take a day off every week in this process. That’s not a problem at all. Mind should be happy too.. Otherwise if you just overuse it without giving it enjoyment and rest, then one day your mind will ditch you! It won’t listen to you ! So keeping the mind happy is also very imp. Also from every chapter atleast 150-200 questions are a must to gain confidence.. More to remember: 1. Mantra: Arise awake and stop not till the goal is reached :) ~Swami Vivekananda 2. This is what Bruce Lee used to say: I do not fear the man who has practiced 10 thousand kicks once but the one who has practiced 1 kick 10 thousand times ! :) So do limited things and become prefect in them ! 3. Also, I recommend all my students to practice Sudarshan Kriya of the Art of Living. It gives you very good clarity of mind and keeps you focused in exams. In fact Nishita Purohit (AIIMS Rank 1) used to practice it daily ! Watch my video “Exam Tips” on our youtube channel (Satnara IIT AIIMS Academy) to know exactly what to do in exam time.. Best Wishes Satnara IIT AIIMS Academy (an initiative by IITians.. ) Mayur Vihar, Delhi

NEET without coaching can be a difficult task as a person can struggle for motivation due to the lack of severe competition that exists in the coaching classes. NEET is an important entrance examination conducted on the national level the scores of which are used for taking admission at top medical and dental colleges in India. NEET is divided into two exams - NEET UG which is conducted for availing admission to undergraduate programs and NEET PG for postgraduate programs. It is mandatory for one to qualify the exam in order to avail admissions to medical and dental courses across the country. What necessitates enrolling in classes? Considering the important role that NEET plays in our curriculum more importance is given to the entire learning process. Besides, there are numerous coaching classes that offer tutoring and guidance in qualifying the exams. However, not many may be interested in spending their time in the classes for hours and may like to self study and pass the exam in flying colors. Without going for peer pressure and falling for hearsay, qualifying the NEET entrance exam through self-study is quite possible. Because nothing is impossible for the heart that is determined to reach its goal. However, for doing so, you need to have certain resources handy that can make it possible for you to fulfill your quest. These include: Determination Nothing is impossible for ones who are determined to achieve their goal. So the foremost aspect is to be determined. You need to remove it from your mind that you are lagging behind or it will be impossible to qualify the exam without going to classes. So first make up your mind that you can achieve your goal no matter what. Also, keep repeating to yourself “I CAN DO IT, I M POSSIBLE” Reading of textbook The syllabus for the NEET entrance exam is based on the NCERT syllabus. Thus, especially in the case of NEET UG ensure to primarily make yourself abreast of the entire portion and topics covered in class 11th and class 12th. A major part of the questions is asked from Class 12th and a few from class 11th. Additionally, first, get yourself well acquainted with the entire syllabus of topics. This will make it quite easy to determine your weaknesses and strengths and which topics you need to begin your preparation with. Go through previous year papers Keeping all your weaponry ready and doing good research before the actual preparation can half sort your stress. Thanks to technology, now it is not a difficult task to get your hands on previous year papers. Go through the entire papers and you can find questions that are repeated through years or chapters whose questions are asked the most. Herein, you can go on to prepare your strategy for preparation. Read through the papers, list out common questions, as well as topics which you consider, are important from the examination point of view. Get good reference books The next important criteria are reference books. A good reference book can make your preparation easier. It will cover all the important topics, as well as help, strengthen your concepts and gain practice. Solve previous year papers Solve previous year papers, online test series and mock tests help to make your preparation a compact thing. Practice The practice is the most important criterion for qualifying any exam. Combine the resources with practice and make your way to success and earn applause.

You require a lot of self discipline if you are to do it all without coaching. Those who go to coaching just get an edge over you and they stay regular with their studies as they get lesser time to self study, which is not the case with you. I would recommend the following- Keep weekly targets. This is because this is exactly what coaching classes do. They have weekly tests conducted each week.Your weekly targets should include MINIMUM 3–4 chapters PER subject per week. Be very strict with your targets.For every chapter, do ncert first. Even for physics, just go through it at least. Then, go for other reference books for theory. While for bio in theory maximum focus should be on ncert, you can use trueman for relevant extra points, for chem, you can use GRB books, while for physics, HCV or SL Arora are good. Do not waste too much time on theory though.Take one standard objective book. Keep practicing every chapter. You may add more objective books, though.Join a test series. You haven't joined a coaching institute, that's fine. But test series is of utmost importance as it gives you an idea about the exam, the questions and most importantly, about where you stand.Do not lose track of what you did last week. Keep revising.Attempt to finish the whole neet syllabus by January. If you're in class 11th right now, finish the 11th syllabus by December this year.

It will be tough. Stick to NCERT course. Revise bio every morning for atleast an hour . If you are in a dummy school or a dropout, then you will get atleast 5 hours more to study. To strengthen concepts of physics, buy Halliday -Resnick -Walker for strengthening concepts. Keep remembering the constants value. Strengthen your basic concepts of maths like logarithms, differentiation and integration, power and general maths which will happen only when you keep solving questions. Buy Arihant , MTG and other MCQ books of your preference. Keep asking questions and solving questions. For chemistry NCERT is a must. Try to remember every fact as there is a high probability that any minute fact can be asked, especially in inorganic. Understand physical and organic. Each and every reaction is important. Solve MTG and Arihant. I would suggest Bhakta and Ghosh for solving organic. For biology rote learning is required. Understand the physiology learn morphology. Baki sab moh maya hai. Solve questions and note extra information in the questions. For those who are in school I would suggest making a time table. Peace.

The number of students appeared this year for NEET UG were almost 11 lakh and next years it’s expected to be around 20lakh. So by 2019 it could more than that. Be prepared for a tough competition as the increment of seats in medical colleges is also expected to be very less for the next 2 years. First, from my personnel experience shut all your future travel plans as it could be a major distraction for you. Secondly, have a firm time table for your studies. The timetable question I’ve answered down below. Thirdly, make your basics and foundations as strong as possible and practice as many questions as you can. Memorize Biology NCERT of 11th and 12th STD by heart and give ample amount of time to physics and chemistry questions. Make your organic chemistry as strong as possible as it carries maximum weightage. Last but not the least, have fun studying the subject and have a fixed relaxation time everyday. Make good friends who can help you with your doubts. Clear your queries with your lecturers at the same moment and don’t pile it up for the last. Remember, becoming a Doctor for the world is a privilege on itself. All the Best and try to score above 600 out of 720 in NEET UG.

NEET is a challenging exam and both self study and coaching classes are equally important. You need to attend coaching classes to get a teacher led instruction to tackle NEET exam. At the same time, you need to supplement your NEET study and preparation with good tools. There are a few Apps that can help you in NEET preparation. One of them I highly recommend is 'The Victo NEET Challenge App'' This App has has NEET challenges. NEET challenges are nothing other than the timed mock NEET exams that are pre-scheduled. Just like your real NEET exam, several students or NEET aspirants take the exam at the same time. So, this gives you the feel of a real NEET exam. The best part is once you submit the exam, You will come to know your score within a short period of time after you submit your NEET challenge and you can also gauge where you stand in the competition among your peers. This will help you change your studying strategy, concentrate on your weak areas more and you will also come to know the difficulty level of questions. With constant practice on this app, you will be mastering not only the syllabus, but also the complete exam pattern.

Just follow this as much as you can.. And you will be there :) - Read this overall guide for your preparation: The Complete NEET-AIIMS Guide: 1. Be sincere in your efforts (Half hearted efforts do not give fruitful results!) 2. Practice from limited and standard books like SL Arora HC VERMA, etc. Don’t go for too many books. Do limited books, and do it more number of times. Become perfect in them. The end objective is to gain confidence. If you are able to get good marks and have gained confidence… That’s it. You are there.. One should create a balance between doing and non-doing… One should not over-do anything! Over-doing brings dullness and self-doubt. 3. Get a good Guru, if you can find ! Guru is the person who knows what should be done and what should not be done. He/she is the best guide. 4.Focus more on previous year questions of NEET,AIIMS and other medical exams that were conducted earlier (statewise). Practice previous year questions MANY TIMES. Become perfect in them. Solve other people’s doubts. That will help you score better :) (Whatever we give to the world comes back many times. Example: If you keep smiling, then people smile at you. That’s the law of nature. You give Soan Papdi in Diwali to people and Soan Papdi will only come back. World is nothing but a reflection of you. Whatever you start thinking, starts manifesting. So always be positive. Never forget hardwork always defeats talent eventually.

Coaching is not must for cracking NEET or any other competitive exam…… First analyse yourself, identify your strong and weaks points…identify whether you are a slow learner or fastAfter analysing see the syllabus for NEET , how many chapter from each subject are coming….make time table, giving more time on subject , in which you face much problem….make small goal each day…and try to complete them on day to day basis..Learn the concept, don’t cram the things, learn them by heart…..learn how to apply the concept in questns…After doing 1 chapter practice questions as much as you can…..do this for all chapter…..try to make some special notes after the end of each chapter…that will help you in your revision later on….Make your Sunday for giving test…..take previous year paper from net…and do questn of chapter which you have done already…..this will help you ,analyse how much more you need to spend time on that chapter……..For any help or suggestions…..comment below…
